Political science has a variety of assessments and quantitative indicators for assessing whether a government is democratic and whether it is dictatorial. The Democracy Index, which is published by the Economist Intelligence Society from time to time, is one example. The democracy and dictatorship index compiled by political scientist Cheibub et al. classifies the democratic levels of 199 countries from 1946 to 2008. After dividing the countries of the world into two major types of democracy and dictatorship, the subdivision of democracy is divided into: parliamentary democracy. Mixed semi-presidential democracy, presidential democracy, and dictatorship are subdivided into: royal dictatorship, civil dictatorship, and military dictatorship. The process of transforming a political power from a dictatorial system to a democratic system is called democratization. In the third wave of democratization since the 1980s, dictatorships in many countries in Asia, Africa, South America and Eastern Europe have collapsed. It is the largest and most massive wave of democratization in human history. In East Asia, countries that have changed from a dictatorial system to a democratic system include Mongolia, South Korea, and the Republic of China. In recent years, the influence of dictatorships among UN members has grown. As a result, disputes have arisen, such as Russia, the People’s Republic of China, Cuba, Saudi Arabia, Algeria, Vietnam and other dictatorships have won international disputes with the UN Human Rights Commission. . Although democracies may not completely avoid violations of human rights, the structural factors of the polity make dictatorships more vulnerable to human rights violations. The founder of the theory of democratization modernization, Seymour Martin Lipset, compares the statistics of European democracies and Latin American dictatorships in the book "Political Man", and concludes that there is a positive correlation between democratization and economic development. The higher the level, the more likely the country is to be democratic.

paragraphs.context: The Rosetta is a robotic space probe program organized by the European Space Agency to study the 67P/Churyumov-Glahimenk comet. Launched at the Gayana Space Center on March 2, 2004, it entered the orbit of the comet after more than eight months in 10 years, and then the Philae lander carried on it landed on the comet on November 12, 2014. On August 6, 2014, it approached the comet by a distance of about 100 km and reduced its relative velocity to 1 m/s, making it the first spacecraft intended to meet the comet and enter its orbit. After further maneuvering, the plan is to approach orbit after 30 km and approximately 6 weeks later. It is part of the basic mission of the European Space Agency's Horizon 2000, and it is the first mission designed to orbit the comet and land on the comet. The Rosetta was launched by the Aryan V carrier rocket at 07:17 GMT on March 2, 2004, and arrived on the comet on August 6, 2014. The Rosetta consists of two main components: the Rosetta detector, which has 12 instruments, and the Philae lander, with an additional nine instruments. The Rosetta mission will orbit the 67P/Churyumov-Glahimenk comet for 17 months and is designed to complete the most detailed study of the comet's history. The mission was controlled by the European Space Operations Centre in Darmstadt, Germany. The detector is named after the Rosetta Stone, and it is hoped that this mission will help unlock the mystery of the solar system before the formation of the planet. The lander was named after Philae, the name of the small island in the Nile, where an obelisk was discovered and assisted in interpreting the Rosetta Stone. The comparison of the pictograms of the Rosetta Stone and the Obelisk catalyzes the declassification of the Egyptian writing system. Similarly, it is hoped that these ships will lead to a better understanding of comets and the early solar system. On its way to the comet, the spacecraft has completed the two asteroids' flying missions. In 2007, the Rosetta also carried out a Mars gravity boosting orbit. The Rosetta Lander of Rosetta landed on the comet on November 12, 2014, which is the 67P/Churyumov-Glahimenke comet, becoming the first successful controlled landing on the comet. detector. Astrophysicist Elizabeth Pearson said that although the future of the Philae lander is uncertain, the orbiter Rosetta is the main force of the mission, and its work will continue.

paragraphs.context: Ta Kung Pao is one of the longest-running Chinese newspapers in China. It was born in the French Concession in 1902. It has been published for over 100 years and was one of the most influential newspapers of the Republic of China during the period of the Republic of China. The current "Ta Kung Pao" pro-China Communist Party has a strong political background. After 1949, under the leadership of the Hong Kong and Macao Working Committee of the Communist Party of China, Ta Kung Pao was published in Hong Kong and its position was close to the People's Republic of China. In terms of cross-strait and Hong Kong, the newspaper also clearly stood on the side of the CCP. Therefore, Ta Kung Pao, Wen Wei Po, Hong Kong Commercial Daily and Hong Kong Economic Herald are known as one of the four major left newspapers. On June 17, 1902, Ta Kung Pao was first published in the French Concession in Tianjin. Its founder was one of the proponents of Fu Jen University, and it was a royalist party in the late Qing Dynasty. Ying Convergence published the "Ta Kung Pao Preface" on the inaugural issue, stating that the newspaper took the Dagong one as the self-forgetting, and the selflessness was the public. The purpose of running the newspaper was to open the atmosphere, to enlighten the people, to seduce the academics of the European Union, and to open up my compatriots. clever. In the ten years of the presiding of "Ta Kung Pao", Ying Confucius advocated constitutional monarchy, reformed the law, and dared to discuss the political affairs. He often published the official documents of the Beiyang government and became a striking large-scale daily newspaper in North China. After the establishment of the Republic of China, in September 1916, Ying Confucius sold the newspaper to Wang Qianlong, one of the shareholders. Wang Qianlong is a representative of the industrial and commercial circles of the Department of Anfu. In October 1916, after Wang Ronglong fully accepted the "Ta Kung Pao", he hired Hu Zhengzhi, who had experience in running newspapers, as the main manager and manager. After he took office, he presided over the reform of the newspaper. From November 10, 1916, one month after Hu Zhengzhi entered the hall, "Ta Kung Pao" was changed from a book type to a bar-style type, and the vertical two columns were changed into four columns. After several reforms, it was changed into six columns. Eight columns. The font size has also been adjusted. The size and spacing of the various font sizes have changed the original monotonous situation, making the layout become patchwork. During the New Culture Movement, Hu Zhengzhi was in charge of his speech during his administration. In a series of major events such as Zhang Xun's restoration and the May Fourth Movement, Ta Kung Pao published many influential articles. Hu Zhengzhi also resigned as manager after interviewing Paris. In September 1923, Wang Xiaolong was killed in the Great Kanto Earthquake in Japan, and Anfu was in the next year. The unsustainable Ta Kung Pao announced the suspension of its publication on November 27, 1925. The Ta Kung Pao in the founding of Ta Kung Pao has always been a book-style, a full-page straight line, divided into two columns, leaving a blank space between the columns, each column has a border, and can be bound into a book after folding.

At the end of the year, the newspapers were sent to the stocks of considerable shares; Wu Dingchang was appointed as the president, Hu Zhengzhi was the manager and deputy editor-in-chief, and Zhang Jiyu was the editor-in-chief and deputy manager; the trio co-organized the committee to study current affairs, discuss opinions, and decided to Take turns to write. Finally, Zhang Jizhen is responsible for the amendment. When the opinions of the three people are different, the majority decision is made. When the opinions of the three people are different, Zhang Jizhen shall prevail. When the Ta Kung Pao was reissued, the circulation was less than 2,000. In May 1927, it increased to more than 6,000. paragraphs.context: Motorcycles, also known as locomotives, Autobikes, and bicycles in Taiwan, are called motorcycles in Hong Kong and Macao, and the Southeast Asian Chinese Circle is called Capricorn. It refers to two or three-wheeled motor vehicles, derived from motorized bicycles. With two rounds as the bulk. Its variety is quite diverse, mainly in the hands of locomotives, light locomotives, speed skating, and American locomotives. Some special-purpose locomotives will be equipped with external auxiliary wheels, such as mentally handicapped vehicles. On some military or police vehicles, a side car and auxiliary wheels will be added to become a special three-wheeled vehicle. The locomotive has the characteristics of simple operation, convenient operation and low price. It is widely used in daily life, transportation, public security and military, and is also widely used in developing countries. There are currently about 200 million locomotives in the world, with a density of about 33 per 1,000 people; most of the locomotives are concentrated in Asia, accounting for about 58% of the world's locomotives. In the history of the vehicle, the bicycle first appeared, followed by the locomotive, and finally the car appeared after the transmission was mature. The world's locomotives are originated in Europe, Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, and the United States in North America. The first market-oriented locomotive design was the Butler Petrol Cycle, a three-engined vehicle designed by Edward Butler in the UK in 1884. The locomotive is powered by a five-eighth 600cc water-cooled four-stroke engine and produced by the Merryweather Fire Vehicle Manufacturing Company. However, the locomotive did not succeed because Butler did not have enough funds. Another locomotive that uses internal combustion engines is the Daimler Reitwagen locomotive designed and built by the German inventors Gottlieb Daimler and William Maybach in 1885. This locomotive is equivalent to a gasoline four-stroke engine mounted on a wooden two-wheeler, but it is different from the bicycle at the time: centrifugal force is not generated by tilting the vehicle, and the vehicle is turned, completely unused 70 years ago The bicycle principle was developed and replaced by the swing of the two forks. However, this locomotive was not used for practical purposes, but only as a carrier for the development of internal combustion engines by two people. However, before the invention of the two locomotives, there were a number of locomotives, electric locomotives and two-wheeled vehicles using diesel engines. If the three types of vehicles are also counted as locomotives, the first locomotive should be a locomotive made by the Frenchman Nicholas Courin in 1769 using a steam engine.

paragraphs.context: In 1894, Germany's Hildebrand & Wolfmüller became the first publicly available locomotive and was first known as the Motorrad German locomotive. The British manufacturer Excelsior Motor Company began manufacturing a self-developed locomotive in 1896. In the early days of the history of locomotive development, many bicycle manufacturers have adapted their own bicycle designs to install internal combustion engines. With the strengthening of engine horsepower and changes in bicycle design, the number of locomotive manufacturers has soared. At the same time, many people who originally developed locomotives in the 19th century, such as Gottlieb Daimler and William Maybach, mostly started to develop cars. In 1903, the famous American locomotive manufacturer Harley Davidson was founded and began to manufacture locomotives. Until the eve of World War I, the world's largest locomotive manufacturer was an Indian company that produced more than 20,000 locomotives a year. During the First World War, due to the great role of locomotives in frontline communications during the war, the demand for locomotives in European countries increased, and locomotive production surged again. The intelligence officers on the battlefield gradually turned from horseback riding to riding a locomotive. 50% of the locomotives produced by Harley locomotives in the United States are war required. The British triumph company sold more than 30,000 H-type locomotives to the Three Kingdoms during the war. The H-type locomotive is equipped with a 499cc single-cylinder air-cooled four-stroke engine, and the rear wheels are driven by a belt. This is also the first revival locomotive that does not use bicycle pedals. The H-type locomotive is usually considered the first modern locomotive. By 1920, the Harley locomotive was the world's largest locomotive manufacturer, and its locomotives were sold to 67 countries. From the late 1920s to the 1930s, Germany's DKW replaced Harley as the largest locomotive manufacturer. In the 1950s, the streamlined design made a foray into the race locomotive industry. The locomotive with large fairings became a feature of locomotive design at the time. NSU and Moto Guzzi became the leaders of streamlined locomotives. NSU's advanced design did the most, but after four NSU racers lost their lives in the 1954–1956 World Motorcycle Championships, NSU stopped designing such locomotives and no longer participated in the World Motorcycle Championships. In 1958, for safety reasons, locomotives using fully enclosed fairings were banned from use by the International Motorcycle Racing Association. From the 1960s to the 1990s, small two-stroke locomotives became popular around the world, one of which was due to the two-stroke engine invented by Walter Kaaden of East Germany in the 1950s.

paragraphs.context: Japan's locomotive manufacturing industry originated from the Honda A-type moped produced by Honda Tech Industrial in 1940. In 1948, Honda officially began producing locomotives. In the 1950s, the Japanese locomotive manufacturing industry flourished, and more than a hundred manufacturers came together. However, the locomotives manufactured by these manufacturers were basically counterfeit locomotives of European manufacturers. In the 1950s, various manufacturers gradually developed their own styles. Among them, Honda Techno Industry, Yamaha, Kawasaki Heavy Industries, and Suzuki Motors' four locomotive manufacturers gradually dominated the Japanese locomotive manufacturing industry. The locomotives manufactured by the four companies are exported to Europe, America and Southeast Asia, gradually making Japan the center of the world's locomotive manufacturing industry. At present, the export volume of Japanese locomotives ranks among the top in the world. In the 1960s, various industries in Taiwan gradually emerged, and locomotives became the main means of transportation, and the overall demand was expanded. However, due to the shortage of foreign exchange, it is difficult to import enough locomotives. The government encourages investment in the locomotive industry and sets the self-made rate, which is increasing year by year. In November 1961, Taiwan Sanyang Industrial Co., Ltd. cooperated with Honda of Japan to produce the first locomotive in Taiwan. Since then, Sanyang Industrial has started to produce 50cc and 150cc locomotives, becoming the first locomotive manufacturing company in Taiwan. Since then, Taiwan's locomotive manufacturing industry has risen, with more than 40 manufacturers at its peak. Since 1988, locomotives produced in Taiwan have been exported to mainland China. In 1993, Sanyang Industrial built the first joint venture in Hunan, China. The first locomotives built in mainland China were the Jinggangshan locomotives built by Beijing Sixth Automobile Manufacturing Plant on July 8, 1951. This locomotive is modeled after the German Schindler K500, using a two-cylinder opposed four-stroke air-cooled engine with a cylinder volume of 498ml, engine power of 11.8Kw, maximum speed of 110km/h and self-weight of 195kg. After that, many automobile manufacturers in China have produced a variety of locomotives. Because they are mostly military, locomotives with sidecars account for the majority. After the reform and opening up, a large number of locomotive manufacturers have emerged in China, but most of them are joint ventures. Among them, there are many joint ventures with Japanese manufacturers, and there are very few locomotives developed by themselves, and the quality is uneven. On December 15, 2000, the first Zongshen 750 manufactured by Chongqing Zongshen Group was shipped. This is China's first large-displacement road racing car. At present, China is one of the countries with the largest number of locomotives manufactured worldwide.

paragraphs.context: The original modernism can be said to be a rejection of tradition, and instead try to use a new perspective to think about problems with a modern perspective. Therefore, Gustavs believes that he is a modern composer, and Flaubert has said that it is crucial to have a famous modern taste. The Impressionist movement sees the eradication of tradition as one of the most important changes, and now it seems that this is actually a modernist movement. In literature, the symbolist revolution has greatly influenced the development of modernism, mainly because of its emphasis on feelings and feelings. On the philosophical side, Nietzsche and Freud et al. provide an important support for the further destruction of this transformation: from the basic principles, abandon the original definitions and systems. This wave of change basically stayed in the standard norms of the 19th century, and participants often thought of themselves as reformers rather than revolutionaries. Since the 1890s, with the further advancement of reforms, there has been a thought that should be put aside the previous standard norms. Change should be more thorough, not just to edit and modify past knowledge in accordance with contemporary technology. Corresponding to this change in art, there is the development of relativity in physics; the continuous integration of internal combustion engines and industrialization; and the application of social science in public decision-making. In the first fifteen years of the twentieth century, a series of writers, thinkers, and artists abandoned traditional methods of writing literature, painting, and music. Similarly, the same practices are commonplace in other fields. Those who choose this approach believe that if the actual thing itself is suspicious, then the rules and regulations used to restrict people from dealing with these things lose their meaning. So in art, there must be radical changes in nature. The production model of this era is in line with the rationality and maximum utilitarian goal of modernism. Emphasis on production concepts that are standard, predictable, measurable, and efficient. paragraphs.context: The sound waves caused by the vibration of the sound source are transmitted to the inner ear through the sound system composed of the outer ear and the middle ear, and the circular energy of the inner ear converts the mechanical energy of the sound wave into a nerve impulse on the auditory nerve, and the latter transmits to the cerebral cortex. Subjective feelings produced by the auditory center. The sound waves are generated by the rhythmic changes of the surrounding air pressure. When the objects are vibrating, the surrounding air is also affected. The closer the object is, the more the air particles will be compressed; the farther the object is, the air particles will be pulled apart. Hearing is important to animals, and animals use hearing to escape enemies and capture food. Human language and music are based to some extent on hearing. When the frequency and intensity of the sound wave reach a certain range of values, the animal's hearing can be caused. The vibration frequency that the human ear can feel is about 20-20000 Hz. As you age, the upper limit of hearing decreases, with intensity ranges from 0.0002 to 1000 dyn/cm2. The resistance encountered when the sound propagates through the medium is called the acoustic impedance. When the medium is air, the impedance is small, and when it is solid or liquid, the impedance is large. The acoustic impedance of the ear mainly refers to the total impedance of the middle ear structure during acoustic conduction, which has a decisive influence on the sensitivity and frequency response characteristics of the auditory organs. The lesions of any part of the middle ear structure affect the auditory function on the one hand and the characteristic impedance of the ear on the other hand. In recent years, a new development method that uses the change of acoustic impedance as an indicator to objectively examine human auditory function is called impedance audiometry.

paragraphs.context: The auditory system consists of the auditory organs at all levels of the auditory organs and their connected networks. The auditory organ is known as the ear, and its structure has specially differentiated cells that can sense the mechanical vibration of sound waves and convert the sound energy into nerve impulses called somatosensory devices. Ears of higher animals can be divided into outer ear, middle ear and inner ear. The outer ear includes the auricle and the external auditory canal, which mainly plays the role of sound collection; some animals' auricles can rotate freely to facilitate "capture" sound. The middle ear includes the tympanic membrane, ossicular chain, tympanic cavity, middle ear muscle, eustachian tube and other structures, which mainly play the role of sound transmission. The tympanic membrane is a thin film structure that encloses the inner end of the external auditory canal. Sound waves enter from the external auditory canal and act on the tympanic membrane, which in turn produces corresponding vibrations. The mammalian ossicular chain is a lever system consisting of three small bones, one end is a hammer stem, attached to the inner surface of the tympanic membrane, and the other end is the sacral floor, which covers the oval window membrane of the inner ear, and the vibration of the tympanic membrane passes through A lever system can be effectively transmitted to the inner ear, the tympanic membrane is the tympanic cavity, and the ossicular chain and the middle ear muscles are all in it. The middle ear muscle, also known as the inner ear muscle, has two pieces: the contraction of the tympanic membrane muscle causes the tympanic membrane to be tensioned by pulling the hammer bone, and the contraction of the tibialis muscle fixes the tibia, and its function is to limit the conduction of sound to the inner ear. The eustachian tube is passed from the tympanic cavity to the pharynx, usually closed, swallowed and opened during certain mouth movements, so that the air pressure in the drum chamber is often balanced with atmospheric pressure.

paragraphs.context: Geothermal energy is the natural heat extracted from the earth's crust. This energy comes from the lava inside the earth and exists in the form of heat. It is the energy that causes volcanic eruptions and earthquakes. The temperature inside the earth is as high as 7000 degrees Celsius, and at a depth of 80 to 100 kilometers, the temperature drops to 650 degrees Celsius to 1200 degrees Celsius. Through the flow of groundwater and lava flowing to the crust 1 to 5 km from the ground, heat can be transferred to a location closer to the ground. The high temperature lava heats the nearby groundwater, which eventually oozes out of the ground. The easiest and most cost-effective way to apply geothermal energy is to take these heat sources directly and extract their energy. Humans have long used geothermal energy. For example, in the Paleolithic era, there were hot spring bathing, medical treatment, underground hot water heating in ancient Rome, modern crop greenhouses, aquaculture and dried grains. However, the real understanding of geothermal resources and the large-scale development and utilization began in the middle of the 20th century, but modernity uses more geothermal energy to generate electricity.

qas.question: What is the natural heat extracted from the earth's crust?
How many degrees is the temperature inside the earth?

paragraphs.context: The basic principle of geothermal power generation is to use the endless geothermal heat to heat the groundwater, making it a superheated steam, and use it as a working fluid to drive the turbine to generate electricity. In other words, the conversion of geothermal energy into mechanical energy, and then the conversion of mechanical energy into electrical energy; this way of rotating the turbine with steam is the same as the principle of thermal power generation. However, thermal power generation drives the turbine's working fluid to be maintained by burning heavy oil or coal. It is not only time-consuming but also prone to pollution during the process. Conversely, geothermal power generation is equivalent to placing the boiler and fuel underground, and simply removing the steam can achieve The purpose of power generation. For high-temperature geothermal water as a working fluid, it is usually treated with "flash steam treatment", that is, it is rapidly vaporized by a sudden drop in pressure, and is directly introduced into a low-pressure steam turbine to generate electricity to generate electricity. If the working fluid is dry and high temperature superheated steam, it can be directly connected to the turbine. If it contains both water vapor and hot water, it must be separated by a steam-water separation device. After the steam is pushed to the turbine, it will be condensed into hot water. If the hot water temperature is still high, it can be reused by flashing or another way. The condensate at the end of the power generation system is discharged into the river after proper temperature control, or re-injected underground to prevent the formation from subsiding.

qas.question: Geothermal power generation mainly uses geothermal heat to do something?
What is the usual treatment method for geothermal power generation?
What can be avoided by condensing water at the end of the power generation system?

paragraphs.context: Man-made geothermal energy is a new way to become a 21st century scholarship in order to solve the huge demand for clean energy in global warming. The original concept has been proposed in the 1970s but has not been taken seriously. It is conceived that the geothermal distribution area is extremely limited. Therefore, it has been proposed to use deep drilling technology to drill anywhere near the underground lava to more than 300 degrees, at least 2 wells, one well to inject cold water, one well to recover geothermal heat, after heating Steam power generation, if the cost allows drilling more recovery wells, can reduce the loss of steam; increase power generation efficiency. Although the principle is simple, but because the required depth of the well is more than 5 kilometers deep, and through many hard granite crusts, the traditional drilling method needs to wear hundreds of high-priced drill bits, which is too costly, and the ground conditions are difficult to grasp, and it is possible that the water can not be circulated. The waste wells, coupled with geothermal heat in the mass media, are not as high as solar energy and wind power, and many factors make people reluctant to invest and stop at the experimental stage. However, the concepts of emerging technologies such as hydrothermal rigs and plasma rigs have been proposed, and the cost of drilling is expected to drop sharply. At that time, geothermal energy can provide 24 hours of stable base load without the influence of location and climate. Construction time, cost and public concerns are Far below nuclear energy; it is expected to be the most competitive green energy and global warming solution. Supercritical carbon dioxide fluid can be used as a working fluid instead of water to transfer heat to a geothermal power plant, which then extracts its energy or drives the turbine to generate electricity.

paragraphs.context: Taipei 101 is an office skyscraper located in Xinyi District, Taipei, Taiwan, with a height of 509.2 meters. There are 101 floors on the ground floor and 5 floors underground. paragraphs.context: The Governor is an official position of the highest or nominally Chief Executive in the local administrative region of the Ming and Qing dynasties. In the Qing Dynasty, the Governor was often called the Governor, the Army or the Taiwanese. At the beginning of the post, the Governor’s post was only a vaginal duty that the court sent to the place to conduct military inspections. In the Qing Dynasty, it became a permanent residence in the Qing Dynasty. The Sui Dynasty in Vietnam also imitated the Qing official system and had the post of Governor. In the Western Roman Empire, there was also a similar position to the Governor of the Qing Dynasty - "rector provinciae", which was also translated as "Governor" in Chinese. Later, when the Western powers colonized the country, the highest chief executive set up in the colony was in Chinese. It is often translated as "the Governor". The original word "Governor" in Chinese originated from the Ming Dynasty. The court temporarily granted the official title of the military to supervise the military. It has the nature of military inspection. "Da Ming Hui Dian": "In the early days of the country, the military affairs were full of martial arts. They were often supervised by Wenchen. Wenchen, the heavy priest, the governor. The governor was called the military gate. The governor is close to the military affairs. Or the admiral." Like the general soldiers, there is no rank of the ranks. For example, Xuanfu, Governor of Datong, and Governor of the Three Sides of Shaanxi, the scope of inspections is spread over several provinces, and is limited to a number of prefectures in a province. Ming Xianzong became a governor of Guangdong and Guangxi in five years. During the Zhengde years, the Governor was once renamed the General System. Since then, the Governor has also taken the civil affairs and became the head of the local military and political affairs. paragraphs.context: In the early days of the Republic of China, the post of Governor was abolished, and the governor or governor became the governor of the province. After 1928, the governors of the provinces were roughly equivalent to the governors of the Qing Dynasty. After 1949, the Communist Party of China set up the first secretary of the Regional Bureau in mainland China. Its status is greater than that of the administrative and provincial governors of the provinces, and all the affairs of the jurisdiction and the local military system. Later, the Grand Administrative Region was revoked, so the current provincial party secretary is similar to the governor/tourist in the Qing Dynasty. The governor is responsible for administrative affairs, and is the same as the Qing dynasty. The provincial judicial department is responsible for the higher courts, and its dean is roughly equivalent to the Qing Dynasty. When modern China first came into contact with the Western colonial system, the term "Governor" was used to refer to the chief executives of European and American countries stationed in the colonies, sometimes with similar meanings to the Chinese admiral. Historically Spain's colonies in the provinces, the Naples region and the Americas, as well as the rulers of the British colonies in India, called viceroy, and Chinese was translated as "the Governor." Viceroy is a combination of the Latin word "vice", literally translated as "deputy king". In terms of terms of reference, this type of governor is more similar to the governor of the Qing Dynasty in China. The term Governor can be used as a governor or governor of a colony or a state or province of a certain country, such as the Governor of Hong Kong and the elected "Governor" of the United States, but generally only the head of the colony will be translated into the Governor. Part of the colony, and the British Union, where the British monarch is the head of state, the local representative of the British monarch is also known as the "Governor", such as the Governor of Canada, the Governor of Australia, the Governor of New South Wales, and the Governor of British Columbia. Japan in the Chinese character culture circle defeated the Qing Dynasty in the Sino-Japanese War. After the Treaty of Shimonoseki in 1895, it had the post of Governor of Taiwan. In 1910, after the merger of Japan and South Korea, the position of Governor of North Korea was established.

paragraphs.context: The Anglican case, also known as the Anglican or the Anglican case, is one of the liturgical rituals in the Catholic Western etiquette. It refers to the part of the American Catholic Church pastoral area that was converted to Catholicism in the 1980s. It was attributed to the Catholic Church in a special parish mode, and the Catholic rituals derived from the tradition of the Anglican Church were used under this. These parishes use the "Holy Worship Book" adapted from the Anglican "Phrath Prayer Book" as a ceremonial book. The Anglican case is divided into a variant of the Latin ritual, rather than a church group that forms an independent ritual like the Dongyi Catholic Church. The main purpose of the establishment of the law was that the Catholic Church of the United States, in order to provide the priests and their followers of the former American sacred sect, can still maintain the ceremonial tradition of the use of the sacred sect after the conversion of the Catholic Church, with the consent of the Holy See. The operation of Xi Li is a priest based on the "Hobbies of the Holy Book" held by the priests of the Angligan parish in the subdivision of the sect. In addition, Pope John Paul II allowed married male former Anglican priests to be appointed Catholic priests after the conversion. Since Pope Benedict XVI published the Constitutional Decree of the Combination of the Holy Communion, believers and clergy who have been converted from the Holy Communion have been able to choose to participate in the special bishopric jurisdiction, a Catholic specializing in the preservation of the Anglican tradition and other Sanctuary traditions. group. At present, there are three special bishopric districts, namely the Special Bishop of the Virgin of Walsingham in the United Kingdom, the Special Bishop's Jurisdiction of St. Peter's Throne in the United States, and the Special Episcopal Diocese of the Southern Cross of Australia. Although the Anrigan and the special bishopric districts are systems formed by members who have been converted from the Anglican Church, they are different in some places. For example, the Anglican parish area is also limited to the special system of the United States, while the special bishopric area is a traditional organization of the Psalms that can be established after consultation with the Catholic bishops.

The earth letter is divided into the upper earth letter, the transition zone and the lower earth letter. The upper ground letter contains the lithosphere and the asthenosphere. It is generally believed that the formation of the asthenosphere is due to the decay of a large number of radioactive elements, which makes the outer lithosphere Slow movement is an important part of the theory of plate tectonics. The ocean is a member of the water ring and a major source of salt water. Nearly 71% of the surface is covered by the ocean, a continuous body of water, usually divided into several major oceans and smaller seas. More than half of the area has a depth of more than 3,000 meters. Almost all seawater salinity concentrations fall within the range of 30 to 38 ppt, while ocean salinity averages about 35 per 1,000. Although the oceans have separate names, they are actually a whole, and these connected brines are often considered to be world oceans or global oceans. paragraphs.context: When the patient's blood pressure continues to be too high, he or she will be diagnosed with high blood pressure. Traditionally, a sphygmomanometer measurement has to be taken every other month and repeated three times before a diagnosis can be made. The initial assessment of patients with hypertension includes a complete history and physical examination. With the advent of 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring and home blood pressure monitors, the diagnostic procedure has changed in order to avoid misdiagnosis of patients with cerebral palsy. The current exemplary practice in the UK is to have a dynamic measurement follow-up immediately after a clinically high blood pressure high. It is also possible to follow up with a seven-day home blood pressure monitoring method, but the effect is not ideal. Once diagnosed with high blood pressure, the doctor will try to find the root cause of the disease based on risk factors and other existing symptoms. Secondary hypertension is more common in prepubertal children, and most cases are caused by kidney disease. Essential hypertension is more common in adolescents and has multiple risk factors, including obesity and a family history of hypertension. Laboratory tests can also be used to identify possible causes of secondary hypertension and to determine whether hypertension has caused damage to the heart, eyes and kidneys. Other tests for diabetes and high cholesterol can also be done as these are risk factors for heart disease and may require treatment.

The economic function of the city is no longer embodied in an isolated city, but is represented by a cluster of small and medium-sized cities that are centered on a central city and maintain close economic ties with them. paragraphs.context: The Ainu is an aboriginal group in northern Japan, or a translation of the Ainu, the Ainu, and the Ayinu, mainly living in Sakhalin and Hokkaido, the Kuril Islands, and Kamchatka. In Ainu, "Ainu" means "people." In the official literature, "Ainu" and "Utali" have both titles. Since it has been assimilated into the Japanese, the pure Ainu lineage has basically disappeared. The official estimate is that the population is about 25,000 and the unofficial figure is more than 200,000. Since the promulgation of the Hokkaido Old Natives Protection Act on March 2, 1899, the Ainu were forced to learn Japanese, and they must use the Japanese name to order the suspension of religious practices and become a member of the tribe. After the Second World War, the Japanese government continued to use the phrase "residents since ancient times" and did not recognize the existence of this nation. Until June 6, 2008, Japan first recognized the Ainu as an aborigines. Many Chinese literature directly refers to the Ainu people who used to appear in the history of Japan, and think that the two are the same ethnic group, but this view is controversial. Historically, the Ainu people have also lived in northern Honshu, Japan. According to a survey conducted by the Hokkaido government in 1984, there were 24,381 Ainu people in Hokkaido. However, most Ainu people tend to hide their own ethnicity, or do not know their own ethnic origin, so the exact population of the existing Ainu is difficult to know. In the 1897 census of the Russian Empire, 1,446 people used Ainu as their mother tongue in the Russian Empire and 1,434 in Sakhalin.

paragraphs.context: In 1868, the last general of the Edo Shogunate, Tokugawa Keiji, returned the National Grand Council to Emperor Meiji, and the Meiji period in Japanese history officially began. In 1869, Emperor Meiji moved to Edo and renamed Shinto as Tokyo. In the same year, without any formal consultation, the "Shrimp Land" where the Ainu people lived was officially included in the administrative scope of Japan and was renamed "Hokkaido". The following year, the modern hukou system was officially implemented in Hokkaido, and all Ainu people became administratively Japanese at that time. After that, the Japanese government not only confiscated the land of the Ainu, but also allocated the land to the newly moved Japanese immigrants in order to encourage the development of these new immigrants to Hokkaido. Not long after, Hokkaido’s population exceeded one million people, and the indigenous Ainu people in the area became uncompromising ethnic minorities on their own land. During the Meiji period, the Japanese government carried out all kinds of assimilation of the Ainu people. The long-standing living habits of the Ainu people were officially banned and became "old natives" in the eyes of the people. They were forced to accept "Japanese people". Lifestyle habits. In 1899, the Japanese government enacted the Hokkaido Old Natives Protection Act. At this time, the Ainu were granted automatic Japanese nationality and prohibited Ainu language and any traditional acts such as hunting, fishing, and sacrifice. Although its apparent purpose is to relieve the Ainu people and impart agricultural knowledge, while defining them as "old natives", it also caused institutionalized discrimination against the Ainu people, deliberately The difference between "and people" is regarded as a tribal people.

However, the Japanese government refused: "It is the right of everyone to enjoy their own culture, to practice their own religion, and to use their own language, but the nationalities that are defined in the UN Human Rights Statute are China does not exist." This statement is clearly contradictory to the previously established Hokkaido Old Natives Protection Act. The protests of the Ainu people have not been broken. They repeatedly presented themselves to the Japanese government and the United Nations as a fact of existence of a minority. In the 1957, the Japanese government revised the provisions of No. 107 in the Hokkaido Old Natives Protection Act for the purpose of improving living conditions and working conditions. But for decades, Japanese media and political circles have rarely dealt with the implementation of this issue. Japan still appears as a "single nation state."

paragraphs.context: On the Diaoyutai Island, the bedrock is bare and the soil is thin, but there are still streams in the island to provide fresh water, and there are also a large number of fish in the nearby waters. There are 6 species of land reptiles that inhabit the Diaoyutai. In addition, the species of the sea snake subfamily inhabiting the East China Sea have also been observed in the waters near the Diaoyutai. paragraphs.context: Since the Han Dynasty Emperor sent the messengers to the Western Regions in the 1st century AD, Buddhist art was introduced to the Central Asian region, China, and even South Korea and Japan through the Silk Road. The Eastern Jin Dynasty was the first person to go west in India to seek law. Along with the efforts of the Central Asian preachers on the Silk Road, a large number of works of art flowed in, and the development of Western art in the Tarim Basin in Xinjiang from the 1st to the 11th century can be witnessed. Western art has evolved from the Greek-style Buddhist art of the country. It combines Indian, Greek and Roman styles. The influence of Greek-style Buddhist art on the Silk Road is still found today in Japanese architecture, Buddhist portraits, and the expression methods of some Japanese gods. paragraphs.context: The 5th to 6th centuries were China's Northern and Southern Dynasties. The North was ruled by the Humin Xianbei, and the Northern Wei, Eastern Wei, Western Wei, Northern Qi and Northern Zhou Dynasty were established. At that time, Buddhist art had developed an abstract expression method that was more symbolic and had graphical lines. This style is considered to be very solemn. At first, the Beiwei-style Buddha statues were dominated by wide, pointed noses and smiles, showing the temperament of the delicate breeze. The backlight behind the head has an upward tip that is flaky. Later, temples and memorials were often set up in caves. The Buddha statue is mainly bas-relief from the rock, and rarely adopts the technique of high relief. The sculpture in the Longmen Grottoes is an obvious example. Until the 6th century, a large number of sculptures were made of clay or cast in bronze. Located in Luoyang, Longmen Grottoes is one of the three famous stone carvings in China. It was built in the Northern Wei Dynasty. There are still more than 2,100 caves, more than 40 stupas, more than 100,000 statues, and more than 3,600 inscriptions. Among them, the Longmen Cave is the Northern Wei Xuanwu Emperor who donated money for honouring his parents. It took 24 years to complete. There are 11 large Buddhas in the room, with rigorous imagery, slender face, high nose and big eyes, and a quiet and solemn form.

paragraphs.context: Sir John Frederick William Herschel, the first generation of Baron, born in Slough, Buckinghamshire, England, famous astronomer, mathematician, chemist and photographer, astronomer William Herschel Son. John Herschel pioneered the use of the Julian law to record the date of the sky, and he also made significant contributions to the development of photography. He found that sodium thiosulfate can act as a fixer for silver bromide. Also created the terms "photography", "negative" and "positive". Classical photography blue sun is another important invention. John Herschel graduated from Eton College and St. John's College, Cambridge. During the school he met Charles Babbage and George Peacock and became friends. John Herschel began studying astronomy in 1816 and produced a reflective telescope with a diameter of 18 inches and a focal length of 20 inches. From 1821 to 1823 he and James Muse re-verified his father's double star watch. This work earned him the Lalande Medal from the French Society of France in 1825 and the gold medal awarded by the Royal Astronomical Society in 1826. paragraphs.context: The Caucasus Mountains have a variety of landforms. The lower elevations on the northern slopes of the Greater Caucasus are mainly covered by forests of genus Quercus, hornbeam, eucalyptus and maple, while higher altitudes are covered by birch and pinus. Some lower elevations or slopes are covered by grasslands and sand. The northwest slopes of the Greater Caucasus also have fir and spruce forests. In places with an alpine climate above 2000 meters above sea level, the alpine zone replaces the woods. The starting line of permafrost and glaciers is generally at an altitude of 2800-3000 meters. On the southeastern slopes of the Greater Caucasus, oriental beech, oak, maple, hornbeam and eucalyptus forests thrive, while beech forests often dominate the higher elevations. On the southwestern slope of the Greater Caucasus, the Colkis forest covers the lower elevations, while the coniferous and mixed forests grow at higher altitudes. The alpine zone on the southern slope can extend to an altitude of 2,800 meters, and the starting line/snow line of the glacier starts from 3000-3500 meters.

paragraphs.context: The retina, also known as the vestibule, is a very thin layer of cells in the back of the vertebrate and some cephalopods. These signals are processed by other nerve cells on the retina and evolve into action potentials of retinal ganglion cells. The axons of retinal ganglion cells make up the optic nerve. The retina not only has a sensitizing effect, but it also plays an important role in vision. During morphogenesis, the retina and optic nerve extend from the brain. The structure of the blood vessels on the retina is different for each person and can therefore be used for biometric identification. The adult retina forms 72% of a sphere, which is about 22 mm in diameter. The center of the retina is where the optic nerve extends out of the eye. Therefore, on April 11, 1713, France signed the Utrecht Peace Treaty with the countries of the anti-French alliances other than Austria, namely the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Brandenburg, Savoy and Portugal. In 1714, France signed the "Rashta Peace Treaty" with Austria. On the Spanish side, in July 1713, the United Kingdom signed the "Anglo-West Treaty" and the "Spain - Savoy Treaty"; in June 1714, signed the "Western Treaty" with the Netherlands; February 1715, with Portugal Signed the Treaty of Western Portugal. The Spanish war of succession to the throne has officially ended. As a result, although Philip was able to ensure the position of the king, the treaty stipulated that the law and the West could never be merged, but France was weakened in the war and the British forces were greatly strengthened.

Is the Treaty of Rashta a treaty between France and which country?

paragraphs.context: In October 1949, the Ministry of Railways of China was established to participate in the railway construction and operation of the occupied areas of the Communist Party of China. During the Cultural Revolution, the order of railway operations fell into chaos. In 1973, Deng Xiaoping took the Zhengzhou Railway Bureau as the key target and carried out the whole road rectification, and achieved remarkable results. However, after Deng was defeated, everything was in chaos. After the end of the Cultural Revolution in 1977, the railway industry was rectified and resumed. Since 1997, China Railway has carried out six large-scale speed increases. During this period, the electrification and high-speed transformation of the railway were also carried out simultaneously. According to the plan, by 2020, the total length of China's railways will reach 200,000 kilometers. In addition, the railway emblem of mainland China was born on January 19, 1950, and was designed by Chen Yuxi and promulgated in the People's Daily on January 22, 1950. The entire road emblem pattern represents the front projection of the steam locomotive. The “human” word abstracted from the outline of the steam locomotive represents the people in the upper part, and the cross section of the rail represents the railway in the lower part. The whole pattern represents the “people railway”.

paragraphs.context: Hanshui, also known as the Han River, also known as the Weihe River, is called the Long River, the longest tributary of the Yangtze River. The Hanshui River is located on the left bank of the middle reaches of the Yangtze River. It originates from the Jushui River in the south of the Qinling Mountains in Shaanxi Province, China. The main stream flows from the west to the east through the south of Shaanxi and Hubei, and is injected into the Yangtze River in Wuhan Hankou. It is 1577 kilometers long and has a drainage area of 159,000 square kilometers. The source of the Han nationality is traced back to Hanshui. Qin Huiwen Wang set Hanzhong County, the name was taken from Hanshui. After Liu Bang received Yu Yufeng in Ba, Yi and Hanzhong, they were all in Nanzheng of Hanzhong County. Because they were called Hanwang, they also used "Han" as the national name after the unification of the world. More than 400 years before and after the Han Dynasty, the economy, culture and territory have developed greatly. The former Central Plains inhabitants of China were called Han Chinese. The Han people have become the general name of the Chinese nationality. The origin of the name of the Han River and Hanshui can be traced back to the pre-Qin period. The north of the Hanjiang River Basin is the Yellow River Basin, with the Qinling Mountains, the Waifang Mountains and the Funiu Mountain as the watershed; the northeast is the Huaihe River Basin, with the Funiu Mountain and Tongbai Mountain as the watershed; the southwest is adjacent to the Daba Mountain, Jingshan, Jialing River and Juju River; The southeast is the Jianghan Plain, and there is no obvious natural watershed with the Yangtze River.

paragraphs.context: Penn State University, referred to as Penn. Located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA, it is a well-known private research university and one of eight Ivy League schools. Founded in 1740, the school is the fourth oldest institution of higher education in the United States and the first modern college in the United States to engage in science, technology, and humanities education. The nine signatories of the US Declaration of Independence and the 11 signatories of the US Constitution are related to the school. Benjamin Franklin is the founder of the school. Penn State is a leader in arts, humanities, social sciences, business, architecture and engineering education, with leading disciplines being business, law and medicine. The school has approximately 4,500 professors, nearly 10,000 full-time college students and more than 10,000 graduate students. In 2006, the school received more than $66 million in research funding, and the research staff included about 4,200 faculty members, 870 postdocs, 3,800 graduate students and more than 5,400 technicians. paragraphs.context: Thunderstorms occur when the atmosphere is unstable and produce a lot of rain or ice crystals. Usually there are three specific situations: the low humidity of the Earth's atmosphere is high, which can be observed by the dew point temperature; the temperature difference between the high and low altitudes is extremely large, that is, the temperature decline rate is extremely large; the cold front is forced by the external force to converge. In ancient civilizations, thunderstorms have great influence. Whether it is ancient China, ancient Rome or ancient civilizations of the Americas, there are myths related to thunderstorms. The life cycle of thunderstorms has three phases, namely cumulus phase, maturity phase and extinction phase. During the cumulus phase, the clouds warmer than the surrounding air, so the air inside the cloud accelerates upwards and quickly rises to a temperature much lower than the freezing point. Therefore, a large number of small water spots, ice crystals or snow flakes gather around the cloud, and there is only an increasing updraft without falling airflow.

paragraphs.context: After the abdication of the Xuantong Emperor of the Qing Dynasty in 1911, Zhongnanhai was occupied by the President of the Republic of China Yuan Shikai and became the presidential palace of the Beiyang government. During the Emperor Yuan Shikai, Zhongnanhai was renamed Xinhua Palace, and the Baoyue Building was demolished and renamed Xinhuamen. Since then, Xinhuamen has replaced Xiyuanmen as the main entrance of Zhongnanhai. Since then, Zhongnanhai has been used as the president and prime minister's office of the Beiyang government, and Zhang Zuolin's Grand Marshal House. After the National Government of the Republic of China took over the Peiping, Zhongnanhai was opened as a park. After the end of the Chinese War of Resistance Against Japanese Aggression, the National Government Military Committee was set up in the North China Sea in parallel. On the eve of the joint army in Beiping, Fu Zuoyi, commander-in-chief of North China, moved into Zhongnanhai. During the civil war between the Kuomintang and the Communist Party in 1949, the Communists officially entered Beiping, and the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China stationed in Zhongnanhai. After the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, Zhongnanhai became the resident of the People's Republic of China In January 1967 during the Cultural Revolution, the Red Guards surrounded and tried to temporarily control Zhongnanhai. paragraphs.context: Changhua City is divided into two terrain areas, one is the Bagua platform area in the southeast and the other is the plain area in the northwest and northeast. The Eight Diagrams Terrace is also known as the Eight Diagrams Mountain Range. It was the Daduxi Riverbed between 30,000 and 500,000 years ago. Under the plate extrusion, the uplift fold caused the Baguashan anticline, and the westward anticline was bent and fractured to form the Changhua fault, which was 5.8 kilometers long. The original riverbed was raised to the platform, the highest point was in the bank of the southeast of the bank, 232 meters above sea level, to the northwest corner of the Eight Diagrams Mountain was reduced to 96 meters. Part of the cliffs of the Eight Diagrams Terrace are steep. After the heavy rain, the landslides are prone to occur. The earth and stone collapsed and piled up at the foot of the cliff to form a rockfall pile. The stratum is unstable, so it is not suitable to build a house here. The northwest and northeastern parts of Changhua City are low-lying plain areas, which are part of the Changhua Uplift Coastal Plain. They are alluvial fans, flood plains and Haipu landforms of the Holocene. On August 7, 1959, heavy rains and disasters occurred. The south bank of Daduxi was broken, causing the flooding of this area. It was called "the August 7 flood."

The Gangdise Mountains are an important geographical boundary between the north and the south of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. The grassland is vast and the cultivated land is concentrated. It is a region where the population of the Tibet Autonomous Region is concentrated and agriculture and animal husbandry are developed. The hydropower stations built on Lake Brela and Lake Conoundo provided 90% of the country's electricity. Since 1990, due to the below-average rainfall and the impact of human activities such as residents' diversion and irrigation, the water levels in the two lakes began to decline. By 2004, the water level had dropped by 50%, resulting in a sharp drop in power plant capacity. Coupled with the increase in demand brought about by economic growth, there has been a serious power shortage in the country and a large-scale rotation blackout has to be carried out. The government installed diesel generators in the north of Kigali as an emergency measure. By 2006, it had been used to provide 56% of the country's electricity, but the cost of such power generation was too high. The government has also developed a number of measures to alleviate this problem, such as resettling residents, supplying water to Lake Brera and Confuto Lake, and investing in projects to extract methane from Lake Kivu, the first of which is the first. The phase is expected to increase national power generation by 40%. As of 2013, the country's population that can use electricity is still only 6%. After the genocide in 1994, the Luanda government increased its investment in domestic transportation infrastructure with the help of countries and organizations such as the United States, the European Union and Japan. The transportation system is dominated by road networks, connecting Kigali with most other major cities and towns across the country through paved roads. Luanda connects a number of East African countries including Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi and Kenya via roads, and connects to the eastern Congo cities of Goma and Bukavu. The country’s most important trade route is Pella and Nairobi reach the road to Mombasa.

paragraphs.context: Luanda is one of the most densely populated countries in Africa, with an average of 408 residents living on land per square kilometer. The historian Gérard Prunier believes that such a high population density is also one of the reasons for the 1994 genocide. Most of the country's population lives in rural areas, and there are still a few towns with relatively even population distribution. Only the savanna of Umtara and the Akagaila National Park in the east are sparsely populated. With a population of about 1 million, Kigali is the most populous city in the country. The rapid population growth has made Luanda’s infrastructure overwhelmed. Several other more famous cities include Gitarama, Butare City and Gisenyi, all with a population of less than 100,000. In 1990, Luanda's urban population accounted for 6%, and by 2006 it had increased to 16.6%. However, this proportion fell to 14.8% in 2011. Luanda has been a unified country since the colonial era. Its population belongs to the ethnic group and language group of Banja Luanda. Today, most African countries are divided by colonial countries and have no corresponding Ethnic boundaries or pre-colonial kingdoms.

paragraphs.context: The Luanda National Song and Dance Troupe is the most famous dance group in the country. It was established in 1974 by President Juvenal Habyarimana and is often performed at home and abroad. Music is traditionally taught orally, and the musical styles of different social groups are also different. The drum is a very important instrument, and the royal drummer enjoys a high status in the king's court. Drummers will also play in groups, usually 7 to 9 people. The country’s popular music is also evolving, and the music is mainly influenced by East African, Congo and American music. Hip Hop is the most popular style, combining the characteristics of rap, Regal, rhythm and blues and dance pop music. Traditional crafts and fine arts are produced throughout the country, but most of them are initially practical, not purely decorative. Woven baskets and bowls are particularly popular in the southeastern part of Luanda. There is a unique art work called "Imigongo" made from cow dung, which dates back to the era when the region was part of the independent kingdom of Giza.

paragraphs.context: After the end of the Second World War, Belgium continued to govern Luanda, the United Nations Trust Territory, to oversee its independence process. The tension between the Tutsi and Hutu liberation movements, which advocated early independence, escalated and finally reached its climax in the Luanda Revolution of 1959: Hutu militants began massacring the Tutsi, forcing more than 100,000 Tutsi The tribe sought refuge in neighboring countries. In 1961, the Belgians who stood on the Hutu side held a referendum in Luanda, and the referendum abolished the monarchy. In 1962, Luanda separated from Burundi and gained independence. What followed was a cycle of violence. The Tutsi in the neighboring countries launched an attack on the country, and the Hutu responded with a massive massacre and repression against the Tutsi in the country. In 1973, Juvenal Habyarimana came to power through a military coup. Discrimination against the Hutu family continues, but the state’s economic situation has improved and the violence against the Tutsi has also decreased. The Twa are still a marginalized group in the country. By 1990, they were almost completely expelled from the woods by the government, and many people were embarrassed.

In that year, the total number of students in the school exceeded 3,000, and there were more than 800 teachers. In 1966, with the beginning of the Cultural Revolution, schools were inevitably affected. paragraphs.context: The period of mechanical activity that consists of a diastolic and contraction of the heart is called a cardiac cycle. Because the ventricle plays a major role in pumping blood from the heart, the cardiac cycle is seen as the active cycle of the ventricles. The atria and ventricles each have a diastolic and systolic phase in a cardiac cycle. The activities of the atrial ventricles are sequential, but the activities of the left and right atrium and the ventricles are synchronized. Take a normal psychological cycle of 0.8 seconds as an example: a cardiac cycle begins with the contraction of two atriums, a process that lasts 0.1 seconds, followed by a 0.7 second relaxation. Shortly after the atrial begins to relax, the ventricles begin to contract for 0.3 seconds. This systolic phase can be divided into: isovolumic systolic and ejection phases, which will be described later. The ventricle then dilated for 0.5 seconds. The first 0.4 seconds of ventricular diastole is called the whole heart diastolic period, because the atria is also in the diastolic phase. Isovolumic systole, during which the ventricle continues to contract, but the pressure is still not enough to rush into the pulmonary artery or aorta. On the other hand, this pressure causes the tricuspid and mitral valves to close because the diastolic atrium provides less pressure than the ventricle that is beginning to contract. Closure of the flap prevents blood from flowing back from the ventricle to the atria. The ventricular volume is constant during this period. This is also the origin of its name. Can be so associated: grab a water ball with your hand, but the water ball has not broken. The volume of the water polo does not change during the process.

paragraphs.context: The heart can secrete two peptide hormones, one of which is atrial natriuretic peptide, also known as atrial natriuretic peptide, which is secreted by atrial myocytes. Its physiological role is to dilute sodium, diuresis, reduce venous return, reduce central venous pressure, and make cardiac output. Lowering and lowering blood pressure, etc. When the concentration of sodium ions or plasma in the blood increases, the venous return increases, causing the atrial myocytes to be elongated and stimulated, thereby secreting ANP. ANP reaches the kidney through the blood circulation, inhibits the renal tubules from reabsorbing sodium ions and water, increases the urine flow, and helps the blood volume return to normal. ANP inhibits the secretion of renin, angiotensin, aldosterone, and vasopressin, which indirectly reduces the reabsorption of sodium ions. ANP can also relax the mesangial cells of the spheroid, increase the effective area of filtration, and increase the sodium ion discharge. In addition, ANP reduces the effective response of vascular smooth muscle to vasoconstrictors, thereby lowering blood pressure. There is also ANP in the anterior lobes of the brain and in the brain, but its role remains unknown.

paragraphs.context: In 1918, the Soviet government of Russia decided to divert the Amu and Syr rivers flowing into the Aral Sea to nearby desert areas to irrigate and grow crops such as rice, cotton and grain. This has led to a significant reduction in the amount of water flowing into the Aral Sea. From 1960 to 1970, the water level in the Aral Sea decreased by 20 centimeters per year; from 1970 to 1980, the rate of decline surged to 50-60 centimeters per year. In 1980, the drop in water levels soared to 80-90 cm per year. However, at the same time, the amount of cotton planted has increased significantly. In 1987, the Aral Sea was divided into two parts, the South and the North, known as the South Aral Sea and the North Aral Sea. Since then, artificial channels have been used to reconnect the two lakes, but eventually they were separated again in 1999 as they continued to shrink. In 2003, the North Aral Sea was divided into east and west sides. In October of the same year, Kazakh announced a $260 million rescue plan to build an artificial dam to completely separate the East and West Lakes and completed them in 2005. The move successfully increased the sea area of the North Aral Sea from 2,550 square kilometers in 2003 to 3,300 square kilometers in 2008, an increase of 30%. The depth of the sea has also increased from the original 30 meters to 42 meters, which also saved the local fishing industry, allowing nearly 100 fishermen to return to their livelihoods. In addition, due to the increase of the lake, the rainfall in the area is slowly recovering. It is planned to plant the local shrub species saxaul in the dry seabed to accelerate the coverage of the vegetation, which is expected to accelerate the rate of natural recovery and attract other plants and animals. On the other hand, the South Aral Sea is still declining due to the fiscal tightening of the Uzbek government. The exposed riverbed has a large amount of salt sand, which greatly increases the impact of sandstorms. In 2014, the eastern shore of the South Aral Sea was dried up for the first time in 600 years. It is expected that the Aral Sea will completely disappear from the earth in 2020.

qas.question: In 1918, the reason why the amount of water flowing into the Aral Sea was greatly reduced was related to the policy of which regime?
In what year did the Aral Sea divide into two parts?

answers.text: build an artificial dam to completely separate the East and West Lakes

paragraphs.context: The Muslim world has several meanings. In the religious sense, it refers to those countries that adhere to Islamic law. In the cultural sense, it refers to Islamic civilization and does not include non-Muslims living in this civilization. In modern geopolitical terms, the term usually refers to a country, region, or town that is predominantly Muslim. The number of Muslims ranges from 1.2 to 1.6 billion, about one-fifth of humanity, and is distributed among many different countries and ethnic groups. Islam emphasizes the unity of Muslim compatriots, although there are many factions. The trend of pan-Islamism and nationalism in the past has influenced the status of the Muslim world. Current reports from various sources estimate that the world's population of Muslims is about 1.2 billion to 1.57 billion, accounting for about 23% of the estimated world population of 6.8 billion in 2009; 62% in the Asia-Pacific region, 20% in the Middle East and North Africa, and 15% in Sub-Saharan Africa, 2% in Europe and the Americas. Among them, the Muslim population in Indonesia, Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Turkey, and Egypt accounted for more than 800 million, more than 50% of the total Muslim population. Except for the Mongolian Plateau and the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, the arid regions of the Eurasian continent are all Muslim worlds. Three-quarters of the world’s Muslims live in climate-ridden places with varying degrees of drought. The Islamic state of the monarchy can be divided into the caliphate, the Sultanate and the Amir. The caliphate is the title of the highest ruler of religion and secularity in the Islamic world. The successor of the Prophet Muhammad is equivalent to the emperor or the emperor. The Sudan refers to the Islamic ruler with independent sovereignty, but does not advocate religious leadership, which is equivalent to the king. The Emir refers to the aristocrats, governors or military commanders who rule a province or region, and has a certain degree of autonomy, but still belongs to the sovereign state, equivalent to the prince or the Grand Duke. No matter what kind of country, in the modern world, it is a country where international law guarantees sovereign independence. In addition, Islamic countries that are not monarchy are often referred to as the Islamic Republic.

paragraphs.context: From the geographical perspective, the coal mines, limestone and iron ore in the vicinity of Pittsburgh are rich in reserves, and the transportation of river ports is convenient, which has good conditions for large-scale development of the steel industry. From the historical development point of view, by the 1880s, the region had developed into the largest steel base in the United States, and its steel output accounted for nearly two-thirds of the steel output value of the United States at that time. Before and after the First World War, heavy industry and railway construction in the United States developed rapidly; during the Second World War, the demand for steel increased sharply due to the war; Pittsburgh entered the "golden period" of the development of the steel industry. The development of the steel industry has led to regional economic development. Of the top 500 US companies selected by Fortune magazine, 21 are headquartered in Pittsburgh, such as US Steel, Westinghouse Electric, and Alcoa. Metallurgy, coke, heavy-duty electrical manufacturing equipment and glass industries were the pillar industries of the regional economy at that time, and absorbed most of the local employment. However, because the region's economy is too dependent on the steel industry, it has caused problems such as serious environmental pollution, high industrial concentration, and a single employment pipeline. In the 1950s, the government began to transform the Pittsburgh area. By the 1970s, the focus of the transformation had always been urban environmental remediation. At this time, the government began to realize that merely improving the environment is not enough to revitalize the city. It began to formulate and implement regional economic diversification policies and shift the focus of transformation to promoting emerging industries. This policy achieved remarkable results by the end of the 1980s.

paragraphs.context: The Pontifical Swiss Guard was founded in 1506 by Pope Julius II. The Swiss Guard is one of the oldest military organizations in existence. The weapons of the Swiss Guards include traditional axe guns and a number of modern weapons. The recruitment requirements for the Swiss Guard include the fact that he must be an unmarried Swiss Catholic man, aged between 19 and 30, and has completed basic training for the Swiss military. The Swiss Guard is a mercenary organization that protects the Catholic Church, the Holy See, the Holy See and the Pope. The team was originally employed by the mercenaries who protected the monarchy and gradually turned into a Guardian-like mercenary organization dedicated to the Vatican City State. The service period is almost between 2 years and 25 years. On May 6, 1527, during the robbery in Rome, the Swiss Guards fought fiercely to perform their duties to cover the withdrawal of the Pope. 147 of the 189 soldiers were killed. On May 6th, it was also an important commemoration day for the Swiss Guards. On May 6, 2006, the 500th anniversary of the Swiss Guards, the Vatican held a grand commemoration. The name "Thirty-seven" is used, so that one, three, five, seven, ninety-five "days" are used. The sum of the diameters of the three-layered altar is forty-five feet. The principle of Ping is mainly concentrated on the western coast, and the elevation of the terrain varies greatly. Because the Tropic of Cancer runs through, the climate is between the tropical and subtropical zones. The north of the Tropic of Cancer is a subtropical monsoon climate and the south is a tropical monsoon climate. The natural landscape and ecosystem resources are quite rich and diverse. The island now has a population of about 23.5 million. More than 70% of the island's five metropolitan areas are concentrated in the western part of the city. The Taipei metropolitan area with the administrative center of Taipei is the largest, with a total population of 7 million. The ethnic group consists of two ethnic groups: the Han nationality and the indigenous nationality: the indigenous people are composed of several tribes belonging to the Nandao nationality, and the Han nationality is divided into Heluo, Hakka and other ethnic groups according to the different ages of the people and immigrants. paragraphs.context: Emei Mountain, also known as Lushan Mountain, is located in Emeishan City, Sichuan Province, China. The scenic area is 154 square kilometers. There are more monkeys along the mountain roads, often teaming up for tourists to eat, winning a big feature of Emei. It is one of the four famous Buddhist mountains in China. There are about 26 temples, and there are eight major temples. The Buddha is frequent. It is said to be the dojo of Buddhism in Buddhism. On December 6, 1996, the Emeishan-Leshan Giant Buddha was listed as a World Heritage by UNESCO as a double heritage of culture and nature. Mount Emei stands steeply on the southwestern edge of the Sichuan Basin. It faces west to the east and runs north-south. The west is a 20- or 30-degree buffer slope bordering the western mountains and facing the Chengdu Plain. It belongs to Emeishan City, a county-level city directly under the jurisdiction of the province, with an area of 1151.4 square kilometers and a population of about 435,000. The city governs 12 towns such as Lushan and Longmen and other 6 townships. The municipal government is located in Lushan Town. There are many clouds in the mountains, less sunshine and abundant rainfall. The plain area is subtropical humid monsoon climate. The average temperature in January is about 6.9 degrees, and the average temperature in July is 26.1 degrees. Because Emei Mountain is steep and steep, the climatic zone is vertically distributed. The altitude of 1500 meters to 2100 meters is warm temperate climate; the altitude is 2100 meters. ~2500 meters is moderately temperate climate; above 2500 meters above sea level is sub-cold climate. The area above 2000 meters above sea level is covered by ice and snow for about half a year, usually from October to April of the following year.

paragraphs.context: As early as 1911, Germany had begun to use hybrid railway vehicles, which are railway-powered vehicles that use rechargeable energy storage devices to assist the traction system. When starting, the motor is pushed. When the vehicle accelerates or goes uphill, the engine provides additional power to the traction device to reduce the burden of the main power source. When the vehicle is downhill, the motor generates electricity to recover energy to the energy storage device, so that fuel economy can be achieved, and individual systems can Save 30% to 40% fuel consumption. Hybrid railway vehicles are used in Japan, the United Kingdom, North America and the Czech Republic. Some of the US designs use biofuels in combination with batteries to further reduce carbon emissions. Early hybrid vehicle development focused on trucks and other heavy vehicles. With the advancement of technology and lower costs, hybrid vehicles have been popularized in smaller vehicles in recent years, such as private cars. Hybrid vehicles are more fuel efficient, reducing oil consumption and indirectly reducing overall costs, which will help spread. Due to the decline in overall cost of use, coupled with low carbon emissions, which is in line with the needs of most government environmental policies, public vehicle road public transport vehicles such as buses have also begun to adopt hybrid vehicles in recent years; the world's first hybrid double-layer The bus began service in London in February 2007, and there are now 106 hybrid electric buses in London. Compared to all-electric buses, hybrid bus technology is more mature, there is no need to build additional charging facilities, and in areas where coal is used to generate electricity, its carbon emissions are lower than pure electric vehicles.

qas.question: Which system does the hybrid railway vehicle use?
